resources.string: List of my cycles, my tests and their characteristics
¡Thank you for downloading Fertility Test Analyzer!
This app helps you interpret ovulation and pregnancy test strips of any trademark. If you don\'t have them yet, you can easily buy them in on-line stores.
The cycle date corresponds to the first day of your period. It can be changed later.
Not pregnant\nThe pigmentation of the test line is lower than the threshold value for pregnancy (5%).
Pregnant!\nCongratulations, the pigmentation of the test line is equal or higher than the threshold value for pregnancy (5%).
On your fertile window\nThe pigmentation of the test line is equal or higher than the pigmentation of the control line. Ovulation is likely to happen in the next three days.

Not entering your fertile window\nThe pigmentation of the test line is lower than the pigmentation of the control line. Ovulation is not likely to happen in the next days.\n However, you could be on your fertile window if you have obtained a positive ovulation test three or less days ago.
Tap the cycle to add it to or remove it from the chart.
Cycles too long slow down the chart considerably.
Are you sure that you want to delete this cycle?
You are about to delete the first recorded cycle. If you continue, the tests of this cycle will be deleted as well.\n Do you really want to continue?
You are about to delete a cycle. What do want to do with its tests?\n Merge all the tests of this cycle with the previous one.\n Delete the cycle and its tests.
You\'ll lose all the test\'s information!
Associated test data is saved anyway
Click here to clear all the preferences.
Enable using flash during autofocus when it is dark
Flash helps the camera with focus, but it will not be forced to be on during image acquisition
If you want test notes to be always visible in My Cycles tests list
If you want the information to be visible the next time you take a picture

A test strip is a basic and inexpensive diagnostic tool which is used to determine hormonal changes in a person\'s urine. It has a chemical pad that reacts with the urine, changing color, when is immersed in during a certain period of time (usually a few seconds).\n\nSome test strips are used to predict when a woman is going to ovulate –Ovulation Tests– and others are used to determine if she is pregnant –Pregnancy Tests–.

Either if you are trying to get pregnant or are trying to prevent pregnancy, Ovulation Tests are very useful to find your fertile days. Unlike temperature charting, which tells when you have ovulated, these tests help you predict in advance the time of ovulation and peak fertility.\n\n Each month your body increases the production of Luteinizing Hormone (LH) halfway through the cycle which causes the releasing of an egg (ovulation). When the test shows a positive result, it means that ovulation will happen in the next three days. Pregnancy is technically only possible from five days before ovulation to the day of ovulation.

1. How do they work?

 The tests have two chemical pads: a test line to show qualitatively the LH present in your urine and a control line to show if the test has worked properly. This control line also gives the baseline color to interpret the test results. If the test line is the same intensity or darker than the test control band, it means that you will ovulate within the next days. When the test line color is lighter than the other line, it means that your body has not released its surge of LH.

 2. When is the best time of day to take the ovulation test?

 From 10am to early evening. This is because the LH is synthesized by your body in the early morning and will not appear in your urine until later in the day.

 3. Should I take the test at the same time every day?

 Yes, if you want to optimize results accuracy take the tests at the same time each day. It is also recommended to reduce your liquid intake around 2 hours before testing as a diluted urine sample can hinder detection of the LH surge.

 4. When is best to have sex in order to increase the chance of conceiving?

 It is recommended to time intercourse after a positive result, the day of the LH surge as well as the following three days after, as this is the window of maximum fertility. However many doctors recommend to have sex once every two days during your cycle if you are trying for a baby, especially if you have irregular periods.

 5. Are there any other common signs or symptoms of ovulation?

 Yes, a Basal Body Thermal (BBT) shift is a very clear sign you've ovulated. If you BBT chart daily, you'll be able to tell when the egg was released based on an increase in body temperature. However, it will become measurable the day after you ovulate. The ovulation cramping or midcycle pains (mittelschmerz) that some women feel, signal the actual release of the egg. The abundance of fertile quality cervical mucus is another symptom, and it occurs just prior to your fertile window. Once you ovulate, rising levels of progesterone and decreasing estrogens will result in less cervical mucus, and the quality of mucus will deteriorate, becoming less fertile (sticky, opaque, white/yellowish, hold its shape). Finally, the location of the cervix can tell you if ovulation is near. As you approach ovulation, your cervix becomes soft, high, open and wet. After ovulation these signs reverse, and your cervix becomes firm, low, closed and dry.

Like ovulation tests, pregnancy tests also work detecting the presence of a certain hormone in your urine. When a fertilized egg implants in your uterus lining, membranes surrounding the tiny embryo begin secreting Human Chorionic Gonadotrophin (HCG) into your blood. This hormone can be detected in your urine about 7 to 14 days after fertilization. HCG level peaks at the second month of pregnancy, then declines. Although low, this level remains steady until birth.

Some pregnancy tests are sensitive enough to pick up a trace of HCG before your period is due. You will see that concentrations of HCG are reported in milli-International Units (mIU) per milliliter. A test with a sensitivity of 20 mIU/ml is more sensitive than one with a sensitivity of 50 mIU/ml.

 1. How do they work?

 These pregnancy tests have two chemical pads, a test line to show qualitatively the HCG present in your urine and a control line to show if the test worked properly. When the test line appears, even fade, it means that you are pregnant.

 2. When is the best time of day to take the pregnancy test?

 First morning urine is the best time to collect a sample for pregnancy tests.

 3. When can I get my first positive pregnancy test?

 20mIU/hCG tests offer increased sensitivity and a capacity to detect a positive result earlier. This means that you can begin testing at approximately 7 to 10 days past ovulation. Nevertheless, a negative within this time frame does not necessarily indicate you are not pregnant.

Most of the time, it happens that test results are not clear and women find them difficult to read. It can be really frustrating not to have a certain answer especially if you have been trying to conceive for a long time. That is the reason why Fertility Test Analyzer app has been created.

Fertility Test Analyzer is an application that helps women like you to properly interpret the results of both ovulation and pregnancy tests. Using our own developed algorithm, the app recognizes the pigmentation trace present in the test pad and gives you your long awaited answer. But this is not the only feature of the app! You can also store your ovulation and/or pregnancy test results and see your body's evolution throughout a cycle or several cycles.

 It is really easy to use, helpful and convenient!

 Fertility Test Analyzer also helps you save money because now you can buy those cheap test strips and take tests everyday knowing that you will have reliable results once and for all.
Follow these simple steps to start using the app:
Take a picture of the test using the New Test camera.
Introduce few data about the test.
Find out the result and interpretation.
Manage your test results using the My Cycles list.
Analyze your data using our Charts tool.

Fertility Test Analyzer relies on the good quality of your photos to provide the best results. If the camera of your device does not have a good resolution or contrast, it is going to be difficult to take the most of our app features.

Take into account that both the resolution of your camera and a good lighting are critical to produce optimal images. We highly recommend you to lean your elbows on a surface and use day light when taking the photographs.
How do I take a picture of a test strip?

Fertility Test Analyzer provides you with three different mask sizes that you can choose to take the photo. Select the one that suits you better and place the test strip inside the strip outline that appears in the screen.
It is important to place the test so the handle is on the right, the control line is in the rectangle and the test line is within the square brackets.
What does the percentage given by the app mean?

The app compares the pigmentation level of the test line versus the control line and gives a percentage. Thus, the percentage is the relative value of the test line pigmentation with respect to the control line pigmentation. For example:
0% - means that the app has not detected any pigmentation of the test line.
40% - means that the pigmentation of the test line is 60% lighter than the pigmentation of the control line.
100% - means that the pigmentation of the test line is the same than the pigmentation of the control line.
120% - means that the pigmentation of the test line is 20% more intense than the pigmentation of the control line.
Why a threshold value for pregnancy tests?
Fertility Test Analyzer establishes a threshold value (5% of pigmentation) to start considering a pregnancy test as positive.
This is important to prevent measurement errors (inherent to all measurement techniques) from being considered as positive results.
Should I use the same brand to compare tests?
Yes, it is very important to use the same brand of ovulation or pregnancy tests to compare results in time. Brands tend to differ in pigmentation levels and results could not show consistency.
How can I get my photos in-focus?

We highly recommend you to lean your elbows on a surface to stay steady, place the test on a white surface and use good lighting. The best light to use is the natural daylight (indirect sunlight is optimal) because it is diffuse and white, producing uniform illumination, without reflections and does not affect the test color.

Sometimes it is difficult to get photos in sharp focus. In these cases, you can touch the screen to ask the camera to focus on that area. By default the application uses the torch as a focus aid when it is necessary (the image is dark). This feature can be disabled in Settings. Once you focus manually, the camera keeps the best configuration it could find, and if then you move the test, you must touch the screen again to adjust the focus again.

If you still have problems framing the test strip in the mask so that it is in sharp focus, you have another tool: the zoom. Not all cameras support zooming. If your device does, you will see a slider on the screen that allows you to increase the size of the image. This increasing is usually done by software and, therefore, the captured image will have a little less quality, but it should not be a problem.

These tips rely on the light conditions, your test strips and your device, so you have to carry out several trials until you find the configuration that fits your case the best. In case you keep having difficulties, we provide three mask sizes selectable at the top of the camera screen. The smaller the width of the mask, the further you could focus and, therefore, the easier it should be to take a sharp image. Note that the smaller the test looks in the screen, the lesser the accuracy that the algorithm will have.
Why does it say low contrast in control line?

This means that you need more light to take a good picture. Try to get close to a window or turn on the torch using the torch icon at the top of the screen (only available if your device supports this feature).
Transforming qualitative data into quantitative data. How accurate can that be?

Test strips give results based on the pigmentation level of a small line, this is qualitative data by definition. They do not offer a numeric value to evaluate results, which often leads to interpretation problems.

 Fertility Test Analyzer offers a solution analyzing the pigmentation level, extracting the percentage value and giving its correct interpretation. However, the accuracy of the numeric value offered by the app is affected by a number of factors, i.e. test quality, how diluted the urine is, the quality of the camera used, your skills in taking a good picture (sharp and in-focus) and a correct lighting. Hence, numeric results obtained cannot be taken as exact values, only a laboratory can give those. That said, we normally get an accuracy better than 95% in our tests.

 Use at your own risk. Do not use to avoid pregnancy or anything where more accuracy would be required. Please consult your healthcare provider for any health concern.
Place the test strip inside the mask on a white surface
Selected date restricted to valid limits.
The detection of the line has failed. \nYou can click the RECALCULATE button to process the image in Low Precision Mode (less accurate than Normal Mode) or discard the image and try again.
Test captured in Low Precision Mode
A new cycle must begin after the previous cycle plus one day.\n
A new cycle must begin before the first test so there is no dangling tests unassigned.
A new cycle must begin before the next cycle minus one day.
Sorry, there is no space to create a new cycle. This cycle is just at the end of one cycle and at the beginning of another.
Camera access required to capture new tests.
Sorry, this date matches the date of another existing cycle.
You cannot create a cycle in a date that matches the date of another existing cycle.\n
The cycle must begin before or on the date of this test.
Warning: Low contrast in control line. Improve positioning.
Warning: Low contrast in handle. Check test positioning.
Permission denied, the photo could not be saved.
This app can save the photos of your tests in your phone, but you have to grant write access to your SD card.
Not enough contrast in control line
It has been impossible to detect the line
Are you having problems taking a picture?
Try improving lighting by placing the test by a window.\n\nNatural light helps to get better focus.
Try to focus on the test slightly far away and, afterwards, use the zoom tool at the top of the screen to place the test inside the mask.
Try another mask for your pictures.\n\nThere are 3 options available at the top of the screen. The lower the number, the easier to get in focus.
